bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to William D. Kelly, March 12, 1938

div1.p: Moran explains the substitution of his own letter for the form permission letter sent from the movie studio.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to William D. Kelly, March 12, 1938
div1.opener:
March 12, 1938.
Mr. William D. Kelly,
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures,
1540 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Mr. Kelly:
div1.p:
Your kind favor of March 8th, enclosing a form letter
for my signature, reached me in due season. Frankly, I do not like
form letters, so I am sending you one incorporating all that the “form
letter” contains and decidedly more liberal in its provisions. I trust
you will pardon me for the substitution and that the enclosed will fill
all requirements.

Should you deem it wise or expedient to use the name
“Johnny Moran” instead of a fictitious one, you are at liberty to do
so. There are no strings attached to my permission in this connect-
ion. You need not fear that I will set up any claims for compensat-
ion, damages or whatnot. If you elect to use a fictitious name,
however, please leave nothing to the imagination as to the Celtic
origin of the man who impersonates the “human guinea pig”, Johnny
Moran. While I have always been a most loyal citizen of my adopted
country I have also always been proud to proclaim the land where I
first saw the light. Although I am now past sixty, my intimates
and friends still know me as “Johnny Moran”.

Should you desire a fool-proof document to cover my
permission and consent, you are at liberty to draw it up and I will
have it made legal through certification at the American Consulate
General here. I am assuming, of course, that the picture will not
ridiculize any of those connected with the experiments whether they
happen to be on the “other side of the river” or still in the land of
the living. You can see I have confidence in MGM.

Hoping “Yellow Jack” will net a million dollars in
profits to MGM, I remain,
